transcript:
Patient: I'm glad we're focusing on my experience with the support group and the negative thoughts I've been having. It's been a challenging week, and I want to make sure I'm making progress.

Therapist: I understand, Jin-Soo. Let's start by discussing your experience with the job search support group. Can you tell me how it went and what thoughts and emotions came up for you during and after the meeting?

Patient: Well, I was really nervous going into the meeting. I kept thinking that everyone would judge me for being unemployed and struggling to find a job. But once I got there, I realized that everyone was in a similar situation and they were all very supportive.

Therapist: That's great to hear that you found the group to be supportive. It takes courage to step out of your comfort zone and try something new. What did you learn from attending the meeting?

Patient: I learned that I'm not alone in my struggles. It was helpful to hear other people's stories and realize that many of them were dealing with the same thoughts and feelings as me. It made me feel less isolated and more understood.

Therapist: That's a valuable insight, Jin-Soo. Recognizing that you're not alone in your experiences can be a powerful tool in combating feelings of isolation and hopelessness. Let's explore how this experience relates to the negative thoughts you've been having about your job search.

Patient: Well, I've been telling myself that I'm never going to find a job because I'm not good enough. I compare myself to others and feel like everyone else is more qualified and has it all figured out. Being in the support group made me realize that many people, even those with impressive qualifications, struggle with similar thoughts.

Therapist: It's common for people to fall into the trap of comparing themselves to others and assuming that everyone else has it easier. This is a cognitive distortion called "mental filter," where you focus on the negative aspects of your situation while filtering out the positive. Let's work on challenging this distortion using a thought record.

Patient: Okay, that sounds helpful. How do we do that?

Therapist: First, let's identify the situation or trigger that led to these negative thoughts. In this case, it seems to be the job search process. Next, we'll identify the emotions you experienced and their intensity. What emotions did you feel when you had the thought "I'm never going to find a job because I'm not good enough"?

Patient: I felt hopeless, discouraged, and anxious. The intensity was pretty high, maybe an 8 out of 10.

Therapist: Now, let's look at the evidence for and against this thought. What evidence do you have that supports the idea that you're not good enough and won't find a job?

Patient: Well, I've been applying to jobs for months and haven't gotten any offers. I also don't have as much experience as some of the other candidates I'm competing against.

Therapist: And what evidence do you have against this thought? What are some reasons to believe that you are good enough and will eventually find a job?

Patient: I have a strong educational background and a successful career history. I've also been actively working on improving my skills and expanding my network. And being in the support group showed me that many qualified people are in the same situation.

Therapist: Great. Now, let's come up with an alternative thought that takes into account the evidence for and against your initial thought. What's a more balanced way of looking at your situation?

Patient: I guess a more balanced thought would be, "The job search process is challenging for everyone, but I have valuable skills and experience. If I keep persisting and working on improving myself, I will eventually find a job that's a good fit for me."

Therapist: That's a much more helpful and realistic way of looking at the situation. How do you feel when you consider this alternative thought?

Patient: I feel a bit more hopeful and encouraged. The intensity of the negative emotions is lower, maybe a 4 out of 10 now.

Therapist: That's a significant improvement, Jin-Soo. This is a great example of how challenging cognitive distortions and reframing negative thoughts can have a positive impact on your emotions. Let's continue practicing this skill with other negative thoughts that come up during your job search.

Patient: That sounds good. I'm starting to see how my thoughts and feelings are connected, and how changing my thoughts can help me feel better.

Therapist: You're making great progress in developing your cognitive restructuring skills, Jin-Soo. Remember, it takes practice to build new habits, so be patient with yourself as you continue to work on this.
